description.full: The ofxCvShortImage represents the color data of each pixel as unsigned char variables or values between 0 and 255. They are a slightly smaller (i.e. less data heavy) way of representing the data in an image but they also have less precision than ofxCvFloatImage. Usually when you're capturing from a camera or video into OpenCV, you're using ofxCvShortImage. Keep in mind though that most of the image operations in OpenCV expect a grayscale image, which you can construct using the ofxCvGrayscaleImage.

methods.name: addWeighted
methods.parameters: ofxCvGrayscaleImage &mom, float f
methods.desc: Copies the pixel data of an ofxCvGrayscaleImage into the pixel data of the ofxCvShortImage.

methods.name: allocatePixels
methods.parameters: int w, int h

methods.name: clear
methods.desc: Clears the pixel data of the image. The image must be allocated again with a call to allocate() before it can be used.

methods.name: contrastStretch
methods.desc: This increases the contrast of the image remapping the brightest points in the image to white and the darkest points in the image to black.

methods.name: convertGrayToShort
methods.parameters: int *grayImg, int *floatImg

methods.name: convertShortToGray
methods.parameters: int *floatImg, int *grayImg

methods.name: convertToRange
methods.parameters: float min, float max
methods.desc:
Maps the pixels of an image to the min and max range passed in.


colors.setFromPixels(grabber.getPixels());

first = colors; // will leave unaltered
second = colors; // change it
second.convertToRange(100, 140); // super low contrast

methods.name: flagImageChanged
methods.desc: Marks the image as changed so that the ofTexture can be updated, if the image contains one.

methods.name: getRoiShortPixelsRef
methods.desc: Returns the pixel data of the instance as a ofShortPixels reference. This allows you to directly manipulate the pixels of the ofxCvShortImage.

methods.name: getShortPixelsRef
methods.desc: Returns the pixel data of the instance as a ofShortPixels instance.

methods.name: ofxCvShortImage
methods.desc:
Copy constructor, which allows you to this:

ofxCvShortImage old;
// allocate old
ofxCvShortImage new(old);

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: unsigned char *_pixels
methods.desc: Sets the ofxCvShortImage from the pixels pointer. Be sure that the pixels are the same size and dimensions as the ofxCvShortImage.

methods.name: operator=
methods.desc:
Copies ofxCvGrayscaleImage to the ofxCvShortImage using the = symbol.

imageOne = imageTwo; // make sure that the dimensions and ROI match

methods.name: operator=
methods.desc:
Copies a ofxCvColorImage into a ofxCvShortImage using the = symbol.

grayImage = colorImage; // make sure that the dimensions and ROI match

methods.name: operator=
methods.desc:
opies a ofxCvFloatImage into a ofxCvShortImage using the = symbol.

grayImage = floatColorImage; // make sure that the dimensions and ROI match

methods.name: operator=
methods.desc:
Copies a ofxCvShortImage into a ofxCvShortImage using the = symbol.

grayImage = shortColorImage; // make sure that the dimensions and ROI match

methods.name: operator=
methods.parameters: const int *mom

methods.name: resize
methods.parameters: int w, int h
methods.desc: Resizes the image to the w, h passed in.

methods.name: scaleIntoMe
methods.parameters: ofxCvImage &mom, int interpolationMethod
methods.desc:
Scales the image passed in to be the size of the current image,


ofxCvImage first;
first.allocate(640, 480);
ofxCvImage second;
second.allocate(320, 240);

second.scaleIntoMe(first); // first is now 320,240

methods.name: set
methods.desc: Set all the pixels in the image to the float value passed in. This is useful for blanking or filling an image quickly. Possible values are 0 to 255.

methods.name: setFromPixels
methods.parameters: const unsigned char *_pixels, int w, int h
methods.desc: Set all the pixels in a ofxCvShortImage from a pointer to an array of unsigned char values, using the w and h parameters to determine the dimensions of the image. The array is assumed to contain color values.

methods.name: setRoiFromPixels
methods.parameters: const unsigned char *_pixels, int w, int h
methods.desc: This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an ofPixels instance. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.

document:
#class ofxCvShortImage

<!-- visible: True advanced: False istemplated: False extends: ofxCvImage -->

##InlineDescription

##Description

The ofxCvShortImage represents the color data of each pixel as unsigned char variables or values between 0 and 255. They are a slightly smaller (i.e. less data heavy) way of representing the data in an image but they also have less precision than ofxCvFloatImage. Usually when you're capturing from a camera or video into OpenCV, you're using ofxCvShortImage. Keep in mind though that most of the image operations in OpenCV expect a grayscale image, which you can construct using the ofxCvGrayscaleImage.

###void scaleIntoMe(&mom, interpolationMethod)

<!-- syntax: scaleIntoMe(&mom, interpolationMethod) name: scaleIntoMe returns: void _returns_description: _ parameters: ofxCvImage &mom, int interpolationMethod access: public version_started: 007 _version_deprecated: _ _summary: _ constant: False static: False visible: True advanced: False -->

ofxCvImage first;
first.allocate(640, 480);
ofxCvImage second;

<!----------------------------------------------------------------------------->

###void set(value)

<!-- syntax: set(value) name: set returns: void _returns_description: _ parameters: float value access: public version_started: 007 _version_deprecated: _ _summary: _ constant: False static: False visible: True advanced: False -->

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

Set all the pixels in the image to the float value passed in. This is useful for blanking or filling an image quickly. Possible values are 0 to 255.

<!----------------------------------------------------------------------------->

###void setFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)

<!-- _syntax: setFromPixels(*pixels, w, h) name: setFromPixels returns: void _returns_description: _ _parameters: const unsigned char *pixels, int w, int h access: public version_started: 007 _version_deprecated: _ _summary: _ constant: False static: False visible: True advanced: False -->

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

Set all the pixels in a ofxCvShortImage from a pointer to an array of unsigned char values, using the w and h parameters to determine the dimensions of the image. The array is assumed to contain color values.

<!----------------------------------------------------------------------------->

###void setRoiFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)

<!-- _syntax: setRoiFromPixels(*pixels, w, h) name: setRoiFromPixels returns: void _returns_description: _ _parameters: const unsigned char *pixels, int w, int h access: public version_started: 007 _version_deprecated: _ _summary: _ constant: False static: False visible: True advanced: False -->

_inlined_description: _

_description: _

This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an ofPixels instance. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.

<!----------------------------------------------------------------------------->

##Description

The ofxCvShortImage represents the color data of each pixel as unsigned char variables or values between 0 and 255. They are a slightly smaller (i.e. less data heavy) way of representing the data in an image but they also have less precision than ofxCvFloatImage. Usually when you're capturing from a camera or video into OpenCV, you're using ofxCvShortImage. Keep in mind though that most of the image operations in OpenCV expect a grayscale image, which you can construct using the ofxCvGrayscaleImage.

###void scaleIntoMe(&mom, interpolationMethod)

<!--
_syntax: scaleIntoMe(&mom, interpolationMethod)_
_name: scaleIntoMe_
_returns: void_
_returns_description: _
_parameters: ofxCvImage &mom, int interpolationMethod_
_access: public_
_version_started: 007_
_version_deprecated: _
_summary: _
_constant: False_
_static: False_
_visible: True_
_advanced: False_
-->

_inlined_description: _







_description: _

Scales the image passed in to be the size of the current image, 

~~~~{.cpp}

ofxCvImage first;
first.allocate(640, 480);
ofxCvImage second;
second.allocate(320, 240);

second.scaleIntoMe(first); // first is now 320,240

~~~~

_inlined_description: _







_description: _

Set all the pixels in the image to the float value passed in. This is useful for blanking or filling an image quickly. Possible values are 0 to 255.

_summary: _

-->

_description: _

Set all the pixels in a ofxCvShortImage from a pointer to an array of unsigned char values, using the w and h parameters to determine the dimensions of the image. The array is assumed to contain color values.





<!----------------------------------------------------------------------------->

###void setRoiFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)

<!--
_syntax: setRoiFromPixels(*_pixels, w, h)_
_name: setRoiFromPixels_
_returns: void_
_returns_description: _
_parameters: const unsigned char *_pixels, int w, int h_
_access: public_
_version_started: 007_
_version_deprecated: _
_summary: _
_constant: False_
_static: False_
_visible: True_
_advanced: False_
-->

_inlined_description: _







_description: _

This allows you to set the ROI on the image from an ofPixels instance. Region of Interest is a rectangular area in an image, to segment object for further processing. Once the ROI is defined, OpenCV functions will operate on the ROI, reducing the number of pixels that the operation will examine.
